wordcram
Class WordCram

java.lang.Object
  wordcram.WordCram

public class WordCram
extends java.lang.Object

WordCram is both the main API for WordCram, and the place where all the rendering happens. There are two phases to using a WordCram: constructing, and drawing.

Constructing a WordCram is done with the fluent API -- first, construct a WordCram, then call configuring methods on it. Like this: 

 WordCram wc = new WordCram(this)                           // Construct the WordCram...
   .forWords(new WebPage("http://wordcram.wordpress.com"))  // set its words... 
   .withFonts("serif")                                      // set its font...
   .withColors(color(255,0,0), color(0,0,255));             // set its colors.

Creating a WordCram comes down to two parts:

  • Give it your text or word list. All these methods start with "for...": forWebPage(String), forTextFile(String), forWords(Word[]), etc.
  • Tell it how to display your words. All these methods start with "with...": withFonts(PFont...), withColors(int...), etc.

After all that, actually rendering the WordCram is simple. There are two typical ways:

  • repeatedly call drawNext() while the WordCram hasMore() words to draw (probably once per Processing frame): 
           void draw() {
           if (wordCram.hasMore()) {
               wordCram.drawNext();
           }
       }
  • call drawAll() once, and let it loop for you: 
           void draw() {
           wordCram.drawAll();
       }

Author:
Dan Bernier

Constructor Detail

WordCram

public WordCram(PApplet _parent,
                Word[] _words,
                WordFonter _fonter,
                WordSizer _sizer,
                WordColorer _colorer,
                WordAngler _angler,
                WordPlacer _wordPlacer,
                WordNudger _wordNudger)
Deprecated. Since WordCram 0.3. Use WordCram(PApplet) and the builder fluent API instead.

This was the old way to build a WordCram: you have to specify everything. The new way, WordCram(PApplet), is much easier, but this will be left around for a while.

Parameters:
_parent - Your Processing sketch. You'll probably pass it as this.
_words - The array of words to put into the word cloud.
_fonter - says which font to use for each word.
_sizer - says which size to draw each word at.
_colorer - says which color to draw each word in.
_angler - says how to rotate each word.
_wordPlacer - says (approximately) where to place each word.
_wordNudger - says how to nudge a word, when it doesn't initially fit.

WordCram

public WordCram(PApplet _parent,
                Word[] _words,
                WordFonter _fonter,
                WordSizer _sizer,
                WordColorer _colorer,
                WordAngler _angler,
                WordPlacer _wordPlacer)
Deprecated. Since WordCram 0.3. Use WordCram(PApplet) and the builder fluent API instead.

This was the old way to build a WordCram: you have to specify everything (except the WordNudger, which defaults to a SpiralWordNudger). The new way, WordCram(PApplet), is much easier, but this will be left around for a while.

Parameters:
_parent - Your Processing sketch. You'll probably pass it as this.
_words - The array of words to put into the word cloud.
_fonter - says which font to use for each word.
_sizer - says which size to draw each word at.
_colorer - says which color to draw each word in.
_angler - says how to rotate each word.
_wordPlacer - says (approximately) where to place each word.

WordCram

public WordCram(PApplet _parent)
Make a new WordCram.

When constructed this way, it's the starting point of the fluent API for building WordCrams.

Parameters:
_parent - Your Processing sketch. You'll probably pass it as this.
Method Detail

forWebPage

public WordCram forWebPage(java.lang.String url)
This WordCram will be based on word frequencies in the text of the given web page.

Returns:
The WordCram, for further setup.

withFonts

public WordCram withFonts(java.lang.String... fontNames)
This WordCram will get a PFont for each fontName, via createFont, and will render words in one of those PFonts.

Returns:
The WordCram, for further setup.

currentWord

public Word currentWord()
This method, and currentWordIndex(), are probably just a bad idea waiting to be removed. They're only here in case you want to display info about how the WordCram is progressing. I wouldn't count on them being around for long -- if you really need them, please let me know.

currentWordIndex

public int currentWordIndex()
This method, and currentWord(), are probably just a bad idea waiting to be removed. They're only here in case you want to display info about how the WordCram is progressing. I wouldn't count on them being around for long -- if you really need them, please let me know.
